docs.snippet: Sepp Blatter, the president of FIFA, cannot fix the officiating problems in this World Cup, but he is at last considering the use of technology to aid the referees in the future.

docs.snippet: When regulation and extra time fail to decide a winner at the World Cup, shootouts do — and there is always a fall guy.

headline.seo: Shootouts Decide Victory, Defeat and Fate in One Cruel Moment
headline.main: Victory, Defeat and Fate in One Cruel Moment
headline.print_headline: Victory, Defeat and Fate In One Cruel Moment

docs.snippet: Hard to believe, but Uruguay, population 3.5 million, is a two-time World Cup champion.
docs.lead_paragraph: The World Cup just keeps on going. It's unstoppable for one month every four years, generating a frenzied cavalcade of villains. Today it's Cristiano Ronaldo being scolded by former Portugal legend Luis Figo after Tuesday's loss to Spain for spitting at a cameraman (perhaps) and complaining about the coach (Ronaldo denies the complaining part); the president of Nigeria so angered by the national team's poor performance that he has withdrawn the Super Eagles from all international competition for two years; and Ashley Cole facing death threats for allegedly texting "I hate England."
docs.abstract: Hard to believe, but Uruguay, population 3.5 million, is a two-time World Cup champion.

headline.main: Once Were Warriors: The Return of Uruguay

docs.snippet: There are eight teams left in the World Cup and three shirt manufacturers vying for the crown.
docs.lead_paragraph: In many ways the World Cup is about crowning two champions: one of international soccer, the other of the global sporting goods business. Which shirt company will emerge victorious as official outfitter of the 2010 world champion, as Puma did for Italy in 2006, Nike did for Brazil in 2002, Adidas did for West Germany in 1990 and France in 1998 and Umbro did for Brazil in 1994?
docs.abstract: There are eight teams left in the World Cup and three shirt manufacturers vying for the crown.

headline.main: The Shirt World Cup Is Down to Adidas, Nike and Puma
